docs.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, medicine's weaponry against H.I.V. consisted of a single drug, AZT, that did not work very well and had awful side effects. Today, at least a dozen new drugs for the treatment of the virus that causes AIDS have just reached the market, are awaiting Government approval or are in the late stages of clinical trials. The hope is that these drugs will help H.I.V.-infected patients "manage" their disease so they can live much longer and relatively symptom-free, much as diabetics can.

headline.main: Drug Companies Turn Aggressive In Promoting New Drugs for AIDS

byline.original: By DAVID W. DUNLAP and LAWRENCE M. FISHER

docs.lead_paragraph: For every guy who ever wondered whether a blast of testosterone might transform him into pumped-up muscleman, scientists now have an answer. After four decades of learned debate, a new study has shown what weight lifters say their bodies have illustrated for years: a shot of testosterone can indeed turn a weakling into a bigger, more muscular fellow. "The debate is over," said Dr. Jean D. Wilson, endocrinologist at University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas, who has studied testosterone for 36 years and who was commenting on the new finding. "This is the final nail in the scientific coffin for this question."

headline.main: Testosterone Yields Bigger Muscles, Study Says
